_prev_prog_3.PHA_OtherTechnique: Event Tree Frequency and Consequence Analysis
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Tank internal valves, redundant fail-safe design, heat sensitive (thermal) valve closure

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility: Safety of the public and environment as well as the safety of their own employees is top priority. The facility complies with the NFPA 58-2011 requirements for LP-Gas storage facilities as adopted by the Wisconsin State Legislature, Chapter SPS 340 for Gas Systems. Additionally, the facility complies with applicable federal and local laws with respect to the safe handling of propane. The facility meets the requirements of the codes and laws with its practices and design to ensure there is minimal risk of an accidental release. If an emergency were to occur, procedures are in place to notify the local Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency. The terminal is registered with CHEMTREC, an emergency call center that provides information and assistance in the event of an emergency. There is also a 24-hour company emergency number that can assist with coordinating emergency responders and recommend courses of action in emergency scenarios.
A description of your facility and the regulated substances handled:  The Tomahawk Terminals Company facility is a wholesale propane distribution terminal for storage and distribution of propane to local propane marketers. The facilitys permanent storage consists of four 60,000 USWG, two 45,700 USWG, and two 45,000 USWG storage tanks with associated loading and unloading equipment. Propane (UN 1075) is classified as a flammable gas. Typically, propane is received in rail tank cars that are unloaded at the facility using compressors. If necessary, propane can be offloaded from cargo liners using on-board pumps. Propane is loaded into customer truck transports using the facilitys pumping and metering equipment.
The worst-case and alternative release scenarios:  The worst case scenario, as defined by the EPA, is the failure of one 60,000-gallon storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (88.6% at 60°F),

resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint. Equation C-1 from the EPAs RMP Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis was used to determine the hazard distance for the worst case scenario for determination of the public receptors. The alternative release scenario, as determined by the Potential Failure Modes and Effects Analysis (PFMEA) a quantitative study of all potential hazards, is a vehicular accident caused by driver error resulting  in breaking a section of pipe, and creating a vapour cloud that ignites after a short time. The team performing the PFMEA consisted of a group of management and engineers with experience in the design, operation, and maintenance of propane facilities.  
As well, a third party engineering company has conducted a quantitative risk assessment of the worst case and alternative case scenarios. The analyses determined that the location risk for each of the public receptors, with the exception of one receptor, were acceptable according to the 2008 modified Major Industrial Accidents Council of Canada (MIACC) Guidelines created by the Canadian Society for Chemical Engineering, Process Safety Management Division for risk acceptability criteria. The lone exception receptor is a small capacity residential care facility. In conjunction with the care facility, and the local fire department, Tomahawk Terminals has ensured there is a sufficient evacuation plan in place for this facility in the event of an emergency.
The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:  The facility complies with the EPAs accident prevention rule as per 40 CFR Part 68, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The propane system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with state laws adopting NFPA 58-2011.  
Five-year accident history: The Tomahawk Terminal facili

ty has never had an accident involving propane that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, or evacuations including in the past five years. 
The emergency response program:  All personnel, drivers, and contractors receive emergency response procedures training before being allowed on site with drivers also receiving training on the facility loading procedures. The emergency procedures cover all components of an emergency including facility shutdown, alerting local emergency services, and evacuation. In the event of an emergency, the typical response would be through 911. Terminal personnel or emergency responders may contact CHEMTREC to request information and recommendations for emergency response measures. The emergency response plans have been coordinated with the fire department; members of the Fire Department have visited the propane facility and have reviewed the safety systems in place. The Fire Department has been given a map showing the public receptors within the hazard distance in the event of an evacuation exercise. The Fire Department has reviewed and approved the NFPA 58 Fire Safety Analysis for the facility.  Emergency response equipment is inspected and tested regularly to ensure proper function.  The emergency response procedures are re-evaluated on a regular basis, as well as tested annually.
Operational and process safety systems: The facility has been designed with failsafe systems and practices to mitigate the severity of any incident involving propane. These safety systems and practices include:
	Restricted access: all operations and storage tanks are contained within a fenced compound. Drivers are pre-authorized to access the facility upon completing site specific emergency preparedness training hosted by terminal personnel. Pre-authorized personnel can access the terminal via motorized access gate. The gate will open once personnel enter their Personal Identification Number (PIN) on the keypad at the entrance to the fence

d compound or using a FOB.
	Safety information: signage is posted throughout the facility to remind occupants to avoid hazards such as smoking and creating sources of ignition, as well as wear proper safety equipment including fire resistant clothing.  Operating procedures and emergency response procedures and phone numbers are also posted and reviewed with personnel.
	Manual and electronic shutdown: the emergency stop system can be activated by pressing any of the emergency stop buttons located throughout the facility. The emergency stop system will shut down the entire facility, close all tank openings, and open the motorized gates.
	Normally-closed pneumatic valves: these valves are installed in all tank openings and at all product transfer points. These valves remain closed unless a propane transfer operation is being conducted by authorized personnel.
	Heat sensitive (thermal) devices:  the pneumatic control valves at the tank openings and at loading points are equipped with fuse plugs which will melt if a fire occurs causing the control valves to close automatically, minimizing possible product loss and isolating the tanks and shutting down loading/unloading points.
	Fire extinguishers: these are located throughout the facility to assist in suppressing a small fire.
	Hose assemblies with rupture protection: the truck transfer hoses are equipped with an internal spring and closing flapper valves at both ends which will close the hose ends during a hose rupture or pull-away event, to minimize product loss.
	Hydrocarbon detectors: these detectors are located near all transfer operations and when excess concentrations of propane are detected they trigger an automatic shutdown of all pumps and compressors, close the pneumatic valves, activate the alarm, and open the motorized gate.
	Query system: ensures that drivers are present during loading operations and are constantly monitoring the equipment and truck being loaded. The system will shut down pumps and

equipment if a driver fails to press the query button during recurring time intervals throughout the loading process.
	Training requirements: terminal operators have several training requirements that they must complete including having a record of training for completing propane specific Certified Employee Training Program (CETP) courses as designated by the National Propane Gas Association (NPGA). They must also receive training for terminal emergency procedures. All drivers must have completed the necessary CTEP courses to transfer propane as well as be trained in the site specific transfer and emergency procedures.  Only approved drivers will be able to perform loading operations at the facility. Records of personnel, driver, and contractor training are kept on file.
	Operating procedures: detailed operating guidelines and procedures are maintained for truck loading, railcar unloading, product transfer, as well as emergency procedures.  These procedures are reviewed on a regular basis.
	Maintenance procedures: regular maintenance and inspections of emergency and operational equipment are carried out by terminal personnel at predetermined intervals as designated in the operating guidelines to ensure all equipment is in proper condition.
	Incident reporting: the facility has a policy in place for documenting and reporting any incidents or potential hazards. All reports are reviewed and corrective action taken as required.
Planned changes to improve safety:  Terminal and company management seek continuous improvement of operational and safety systems to minimize the risk of incidents, injuries and propane releases. This includes the ongoing training of personnel and the review and maintenance of operating guidelines and emergency procedures. Processes, procedures and facilities will be reviewed regularly and appropriate improvements to safety and operational systems will be implemented as required.
